# What the Salt Learned

You knew the ocean by its lapses —
how it pulled, diluted, how it left
the cold in things that float.

But this was not a lapse.

This was salt
caught red-handed on the breakwater of your skin,
not swimming, not drifting, but *stuck*,
each grain a small percussionist
hitting the drumskin of what you'd opened.

The body has protocols for foreign bodies.
You learned them the hard way:
ingestion means stomach, means breakdown,
means the warm thin soup
of self-dissolution. But this —
this sat on the tendon of your wrist
like something brought in from another climate,
crustal and final,
and you could see it doing things
to tissue, rearranging capillaries
the way a thumb bends light.

It was not pretty.

The whites of your knuckles said *no photo*
but the ocean had already photocopied
every contour — how the salt held
at the crease where wrist becomes forearm,
how it drew its own demarcation line,
a thin arrested lake
where blood refused to read as water.

You touched it. Your finger came back white.
Not the white of clean,
but that other white, the one
you find on bones in parking lots,
on the limestone of old fizzing teeth.

It kept dissolving something.
Some soft architecture beneath the dermis.
And there — at the site of contact —
a whitening, a lifting,
the beginning of a room
the body will fill with oil later,
with honey, with the green crook
of an applied fern.

But for now: this diamond dust
doing its work on collagen,
each grain pressing its square lattice
into what you were, tightening
the matrix, hardening
the soft argument between bone and flesh.

You watched it. You could not stop watching.
The ocean had just taught itself
a new way to close a wound —
not by covering, not by current,
but by becoming the problem
it then solved inside the flesh.

And there was beauty in that.
There was a kind of order
you'd have to call cruel.
The body makes its own lapidary.
The salt learned
how to make a stone
out of the very place it cut.

## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The central conceit — salt crystallizing on a wound as if it were precious stone, the body's response to an external agent at the cellular level — is genuinely original. The poem earns this by grounding everything in medical and molecular fact: "crystallization at the cellular level," "tissue rearranging capillaries / the way a thumb bends light," "a whitening, a lifting" of dermis. That final physical image has real force because it's grounded.

The line "the ocean had already photocopied / every contour — how the salt held" works well: the photocopier metaphor gives the reader something precise to hold against the strangeness of salt tracing skin contours. The closing rotation — wound-cutter-solution becoming stone-out-of-the-place-it-cut — is a genuine argument, not just sentiment.

The short line breaks are doing real work almost everywhere. "Not swimming, not drifting" lands hard because it's enjambed with "but *stuck*" and the asterisk creates a flicker of emphasis that mirrors the strangeness of salt refusing to move. "A thin arrested lake / where blood refused to read as water" — that refusal is concrete.

The shift from ocean-as-figura-tion to something happening on a wrist is structurally sound: the poem starts with landscape and arrives at body, which is exactly where it should go if this is a wound-poem.

### What Isn't Working

**Overcrowded imagery / decorative excess (lines 17–28).** The passage from "the whites of your knuckles said *no photo*" through to the end is too dense with nouns and visual descriptors. "The ocean had already photocopied / every contour — how the salt held / at the crease where wrist becomes forearm, / a thin arrested lake / where blood refused to read as water" — this collapses under its own detail. The reader can't hold four simultaneous visual metaphors (photocopy, lake, refusal-of-reading-as-water) without dropping some. **Direction:** Cut one of these three images or let them operate sequentially rather than stacked. Choose the sharpest one and develop it.

**Abstraction in the middle (lines 13–20).** "You learned them the hard way" — this is explanation, not poem. The body's protocols are named but not rendered. "Ingestion means stomach, means breakdown, / means the warm thin soup / of self-dissolution." This is taxonomy, and it slows momentum when the poem should be accelerating toward the wound. **Direction:** Cut or compress the digestive-protocol passage entirely. Stay in the wrist.

# What the Salt Learned

You knew the ocean by its lapses —
how it pulled, diluted, how it left
the cold in things that float.

But this was not a lapse.

This was salt
perched on the tendon of your wrist,
not swimming, not drifting, but *lodged*,
each grain a small percussionist
hitting the drumskin of what you'd opened.

The body has protocols for foreign bodies.
You learned them the hard way:
ingestion means stomach, means breakdown,
means the warm thin soup
of self-dissolution. But this —
this clung to the crease where wrist becomes forearm,
crustal and final,
and you could see it doing things
to tissue, rearranging capillaries
the way a thumb bends light.

Your finger came back white.
Not the clean white of clean,
but that other white, the one
on bones in parking lots,
on limestone teeth beginning to dissolve.

It kept dissolving something —
some soft architecture beneath the dermis.
At the site of contact: whitening. Lifting.
The body will fill this room later
with oil and honey, with the green crook
of an applied fern.

You watched it. Your tongue pressed against the roof of your mouth,
a nerve-flare, a kind of taste
that had no name but could not be called pretty —
light turned from reading water.

The ocean had just taught itself
a new way to close a wound —
not by covering, not by current,
but by becoming the problem it then solved inside the flesh.

And there was beauty in that.
There was an order — cruel
as a mother tongue turning on its child,
the body's own lapidary school:
the salt learned
how to make a stone
out of the very place it cut.

Salt

Gained — each grain a small percussionist
hitting the drumskin of what you'd opened.

Tissue bends. Capillaries press out around a foreign constant.
Not swimming, not drifting,
but lodged: each grain hardening the wet it touched,
a thin crust pulling at the edges of the wound.

At the wrist-forearm crease — salt draws
the water in like tallow over wax.
The skin pulls back. Salt left behind
its own slow architecture: a white chalk line
where flesh meets tendon, each crystal
pressed out of the cut itself,
becoming the place it then hardens into.

Under magnification, what enters through the mouth
finds no still life — crushed against enamel,
tracked into throat, pressed open at the hinge joint
where fluid gives way to tissue,
and salt learns its lesson:
how to become the scar it then closes.

A nerve-flare. A sharp taste.

Finger came back lifted. Whitening.
Lifting.

Later: oil and fern — the body's green crook,
honeyed, almost domestic
on what the wound undoes.

The white line at the wrist was not healing.
Salt learned how to become
the place it then hardens into:
not by covering but by becoming part of what the flesh peels back.
